params.text:
The AP College Board offers two different computer science courses - AP Computer Science Principles (this class) and AP Computer Science A (the next class).

Again, this course is the first course in the sequence, AP Computer Science Principles (AP CSP), which is an introductory college-level computing course that introduces students to the breadth of the field of computer science.

The AP College Board defines five Big Ideas, or principles, for the AP CSP framework:

💡 Creative Development (CRD),

💡 Data (DAT),

💡 Algorithms and Programming (AAP),

💡 Computing Systems and Networks (CSN), and

💡 Impact of Computing (IOC).

This course consists of seven main units, with the big ideas of the College Board's curricular framework spiraled across all units.

Throughout this course, we will be learning about the principles of computer science from the perspective of mobile computing - a robust, rapidly evolving field that focuses on mobile devices, such as tablets and smart phones. 

We will use the mobile programming language, App Inventor, to program mobile apps for use on both Android and iOS platforms.  You will learn how to design and build mobile apps – apps that are aware of their location, apps that send and receive text messages, apps that give advice and directions.  The only limit on the types of apps you will learn to build is your own imagination.  So, in this course you will learn coding or computer programming.

YES!  But computer science is not just about coding.  So, we will also learn broadly about the fundamental principles of computer science.  We will learn about

  • the potential and the limitations of computing and coding;
  • how to manipulate large data sets and about the importance of data in today's computing environment;
  • how the Internet works and how encryption is used to protect our Internet transactions;
  • about the positive and negative aspects of computing in today's society;
  • and lots more!

panels.title: So I will be learning to code?

params.text:
In addition to the associated skills of the CSP framework, fundamental thinking practices are developmentally sequenced and spiraled across the units, building on each other. 

The six Computational Thinking Practices are:

  • Computational Solution Design,
  • Algorithms and Program Development,
  • Abstraction in Program Development,
  • Code Analysis,
  • Computing Innovations, and
  • Responsible Computing
